headline: Altria Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Adelman with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Adelman with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mike, I want to ask you about price gaps and Marlboro. The brand used to be able or had historically grown share at higher price gaps than currently exist versus price value brands in the marketplace. And I'm curious, with higher cigarette prices overall
componenttext: Mike, I want to ask you about price gaps and Marlboro. The brand used to be able or had historically grown share at higher price gaps than currently exist versus price value brands in the marketplace. And I'm curious, with higher cigarette prices overall because of higher taxes and so forth, do you think that those historical benchmarks of where the brand can grow are still relevant? And if so, what's the principal limiting factor in getting back to those levels of price gaps? Is it more the economy or the competitive dynamics in the marketplace or both?

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think if you look at history, you're right that the Marlboro brand has sustained gaps in the low to mid-40s and in fact, even higher than that during some periods of time. But if you also look at that history in a little  more detail, what you see
componenttext: Well, I think if you look at history, you're right that the Marlboro brand has sustained gaps in the low to mid-40s and in fact, even higher than that during some periods of time. But if you also look at that history in a little  more detail, what you see is that there's a very real relationship between unemployment and consumer confidence and the ability to sustain higher gaps. And so right now, you continue to have high unemployment and you continue to have low consumer confidence. So the brand is performing quite nicely with gaps in the mid-30s. And I think as the economy improves, which it inevitably I think will, the possibility exists for the brand to withstand wider gaps. But I think you have to be sensitive to the fact that our history tells us that the unemployment numbers and the confidence numbers has a bearing on what the consumer is willing to pay at any given point in time, and so we try to be sensitive to that. I'd also say the U.S. market is not one big market, it’s a market that's broken down into pieces, and so there's variability between states, between tax jurisdictions, between areas of higher unemployment versus lower unemployment. And there's variation in gaps because our pricing is managed not just on a national list price basis but also on a state and region basis. And it considers other factors, that's one of the reasons why we're able to show margin expansion, it’s because we can be more surgical in the way we manage gaps across the country.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Christine Farkas with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Christine Farkas with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just on your comments about the high unemployment, I want to understand if in those states where high unemployment really remains stubborn and hasn't moved, if those price gaps are stable or if you found it necessary perhaps to adjust them down a little b
componenttext: Just on your comments about the high unemployment, I want to understand if in those states where high unemployment really remains stubborn and hasn't moved, if those price gaps are stable or if you found it necessary perhaps to adjust them down a little bit further?

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say things are reasonably stable. There are other factors, Christine, like competitive activity that can drive price gaps in markets, not just unemployment and consumer confidence. So sometimes that can have a bearing on what activity goes i
componenttext: Well, I would say things are reasonably stable. There are other factors, Christine, like competitive activity that can drive price gaps in markets, not just unemployment and consumer confidence. So sometimes that can have a bearing on what activity goes into the marketplace. But I think relative to those two factors there's reasonable stability. I don't think that we're seeing that move around a whole lot, and I think that's somewhat reflected in the performance of the business. Market is reasonably stable.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Moving to Wine if I could. Just curious there, given the deload that you've talked about and yet at retail we're seeing good consumer takeaway of higher-end brands. I’m wondering if it's competitive activity or something else that you're seeing, and wha
componenttext: Moving to Wine if I could. Just curious there, given the deload that you've talked about and yet at retail we're seeing good consumer takeaway of higher-end brands. I’m wondering if it's competitive activity or something else that you're seeing, and what leads you to get some comfort that, that actually reverses or improves in the fourth quarter?

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's really a quarter phenomenon more than anything for the year. That business is doing fine and the income for the business is up, just a bit ahead of the total income for the company. So I wouldn't get overly exercised about it. It appears to b
componenttext: I think it's really a quarter phenomenon more than anything for the year. That business is doing fine and the income for the business is up, just a bit ahead of the total income for the company. So I wouldn't get overly exercised about it. It appears to be some inventory movement that I don't think is in the long term going to be meaningful.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: My last question, again talking about the segments that are a bit slower, certainly Cigarettes and Smokeless were solid. But in Cigars, can you discuss a little bit about this competitive activity and why your brands are still losing share here and how yo
componenttext: My last question, again talking about the segments that are a bit slower, certainly Cigarettes and Smokeless were solid. But in Cigars, can you discuss a little bit about this competitive activity and why your brands are still losing share here and how you think that changes going forward?

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I mentioned this in our last earnings call that we were seeing a lot of competitive activity in the Cigar business in the first half, and at that time we said that we would be responding to that. So we have and I think Black & Mild has responded wel
componenttext: Well, I mentioned this in our last earnings call that we were seeing a lot of competitive activity in the Cigar business in the first half, and at that time we said that we would be responding to that. So we have and I think Black & Mild has responded well. The share has turned a corner and started back up. So I think we're getting the kind of effect that we wanted, although there's some cost associated with that. And so let's see how that plays out here over time. But our interest is in having the brand grow with equity-building activities and so some of what we've done in the second half is launched Royale, another SKU of Black & Mild, and we're seeing some early-on positive momentum from that as well. So we have other initiatives beyond that, that think we will help support this business and also allow us to grow the margin back up a bit following this kind of spate of extraordinary competitive activity.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: But the category is growing low-single digits so it's not structural to the category. This is really brand-specific and competitive pricing.
componenttext: But the category is growing low-single digits so it's not structural to the category. This is really brand-specific and competitive pricing.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think that's right.
componenttext: I think that's right.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Nik Modi with UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Nik Modi with UBS.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Quick question for you Mike, in over the past few months we've seen several deep discount players either go bankrupt or exit business and expect more I guess would follow, given some of pressures from the FDA. Have you seen any of this play out in the mar
componenttext: Quick question for you Mike, in over the past few months we've seen several deep discount players either go bankrupt or exit business and expect more I guess would follow, given some of pressures from the FDA. Have you seen any of this play out in the marketplace, in terms of where those consumers are migrating or what retailers are doing? Because by my estimation, some of the few that have gone belly up are at least one share point of the market, which is a pretty big number. Same perspective on that would be helpful. And then my second is, I estimate that Copenhagen Wintergreen has been about half of the growth of the overall Smokeless business. Is that insane of a number, or do you think that's kind of in the ballpark?

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, as to your second question, I haven't looked at it that way so I'd hesitate to tell you that I think you're right. I just haven't examined it from that perspective. I think it's more complicated than that, when you start looking at growth in the cat
componenttext:
Well, as to your second question, I haven't looked at it that way so I'd hesitate to tell you that I think you're right. I just haven't examined it from that perspective. I think it's more complicated than that, when you start looking at growth in the category. But nonetheless, Copenhagen Wintergreen has performed pretty well. 
Relative to your first question, we haven't seen a lot of change. It's pretty stable this year, relationship between the overall Discount segment, Premium segment with movement between brands within each segment. So the old brands coming in and some, particularly in the deep discount end of the business you see some brands come in and they grow and then something happens and somebody else starts to grow. So the business moves around somewhat between brands. That's gone on for a while. And frankly, the fact that some people exit probably doesn't have much impact on the overall dynamic in the category, it just continues to facilitate that movement between different brands within the discount segment.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Chris Burritt of Bloomberg News.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Chris Burritt of Bloomberg News.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mike, I wanted to ask, as you have seen greater interest in Smokeless, I wonder whether you can say that you have lost smokers of Marlboro cigarettes or your other brands to Smokeless products or are you finding that users continue to use both products?
componenttext: Mike, I wanted to ask, as you have seen greater interest in Smokeless, I wonder whether you can say that you have lost smokers of Marlboro cigarettes or your other brands to Smokeless products or are you finding that users continue to use both products?

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the dynamics at work would indicate that there's movement between the Cigarette category and the Smokeless category. There's movement of consumption. Some of that movement is people smoking fewer cigarettes and using smokeless tobacco as an
componenttext: Well, I think the dynamics at work would indicate that there's movement between the Cigarette category and the Smokeless category. There's movement of consumption. Some of that movement is people smoking fewer cigarettes and using smokeless tobacco as an alternative, some of it is people switching from cigarette smoking to smokeless tobacco. It's kind of hard to quantify exactly what's what. But clearly there's movement there, and I think that, that movement would include Marlboro.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: These display changes that you're suggesting or helping with at retail, year in, year out, racks seem to be about the same behind the counter, is this the biggest change in retail display in the tobacco industry for many years, or is it not that big of a
componenttext: These display changes that you're suggesting or helping with at retail, year in, year out, racks seem to be about the same behind the counter, is this the biggest change in retail display in the tobacco industry for many years, or is it not that big of a deal?

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it depends on the store but in many cases it's really a reallocation of the space so that the fixtures there in the stores can accommodate the necessary inventory levels on Smokeless Tobacco to meet the sales requirements in those stores and
componenttext: Well, I think it depends on the store but in many cases it's really a reallocation of the space so that the fixtures there in the stores can accommodate the necessary inventory levels on Smokeless Tobacco to meet the sales requirements in those stores and in some of those cases that space is coming from Cigarette rack space because of the inventory necessary to meet the sales demand of the Cigarette business can be accommodated with less footage of space. So I don't know that, that is what I would describe as a huge change in the presentation of overall Tobacco in the retail store, as much as it is a better management of inventory for the retailer so that they can meet their consumer demand and maintain appropriate inventory positions in their stores. I think that's the way to look at it. There are situations where the categories are not presented together or they're not efficiently displayed in the store. And so there's some opportunity for retailers to improve that situation as well. But I think in most cases, it really is a reallocation of space to meet changing dynamics that have occurred over the last couple of years in the categories.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Philip Gorham of Morningstar.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Philip Gorham of Morningstar.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just one question actually, if you had just portrayed inventory movements on this Cigarette side, it looks as if you had a sequential uptick in shipment declines. My question is, is there anything to read into that in terms of consumer behavior or was tha
componenttext: Just one question actually, if you had just portrayed inventory movements on this Cigarette side, it looks as if you had a sequential uptick in shipment declines. My question is, is there anything to read into that in terms of consumer behavior or was that just something perhaps related to the market share decline at the discount end?

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm not quite sure which category you're referring to. You're talking about the Cigarette business?
componenttext: I'm not quite sure which category you're referring to. You're talking about the Cigarette business?

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't think that we've seen an uptick. I think it's pretty much on the historical price elasticity model. So I think that it's pretty stable within that model.
componenttext: I don't think that we've seen an uptick. I think it's pretty much on the historical price elasticity model. So I think that it's pretty stable within that model.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just one more quick question, in light of the disappearance of some deep discounters in the last few months, is it not quite surprising that you've lost share at the discount end? I would expected you would have been able to gain some there, so what else
componenttext: Just one more quick question, in light of the disappearance of some deep discounters in the last few months, is it not quite surprising that you've lost share at the discount end? I would expected you would have been able to gain some there, so what else is playing into that?

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think when you're talking about people exiting the marketplace, what you're really talking about are deep discount players. So we really don't play in the deep discount business. So we tend to have some interaction between Marlboro and the more premium
componenttext: I think when you're talking about people exiting the marketplace, what you're really talking about are deep discount players. So we really don't play in the deep discount business. So we tend to have some interaction between Marlboro and the more premium and higher-priced end of the discount segment. So you see Marlboro being successful in picking up some of that market share. But it would be unlikely that we would pick up deep discount share because we really don't have an entry there.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your final question comes from the line of Adam Spielman with Citi.
componenttext: Your final question comes from the line of Adam Spielman with Citi.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: When you say there has been more intense activity in Cigars, do I take it that you're talking really about pricing, more aggressive discounting as opposed to more aggressive new product innovations?
componenttext: When you say there has been more intense activity in Cigars, do I take it that you're talking really about pricing, more aggressive discounting as opposed to more aggressive new product innovations?

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's both.
componenttext: It's both.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is there one particular player doing that, or is it general across the...
componenttext: Is there one particular player doing that, or is it general across the...

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, more than one player.
componenttext: No, more than one player.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: As the FDA brings in regulations on packaging and other things, has it actually made any detectable difference to your volumes or pricing, would you say?
componenttext: As the FDA brings in regulations on packaging and other things, has it actually made any detectable difference to your volumes or pricing, would you say?

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, not really.
componenttext: No, not really.
